This is going to sound stupid but would something like f: X --> X where X is empty work? Does this count as being injective or even being a function?

Hey Brantley, I had a quick question about P7. on Set #18. It's basically saying if I have f(x) in Zp[x] and u is a unit in Zp[x]_f(x) then u^phi(f(x) = 1. (and a similar statement in Z[i]].)

However in P1 I defined phi(f(x)) as the number of units in Zp[x]_f(x), which I believe would make this problem quite trivial (unless I am mistaken — I have a proof very similar to how we proved fermat's little theorem in mind). I was wondering if this type of definition for phi(f(x)) would cause me issues in the future. Thank you!
Will do, thanks so much!

Hi Brantley, I'm currently working on P7 of Set #17 where it asks for a formula for φ(n) and two different proofs. I know the proof where we use φ(p^k) = p^k - p^(k-1) and then we prove φ(ab)= φ(a)φ(b) and then we generalize it to all n using prime factorization. Is there another direction I could go down to prove this formula? thanks!
Thanks so much!
